channel.title: 纽约时报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title: President Biden defended his decision to end America's 20-year war in Afghanistan, a day after the U.S. closed a two-week evacuation of 125,000 people from Kabul that saw the deaths of 13 U.S. service members and dozens of Afghan civilians. https://t.co/G5eSF6iiRV https://t.co/zy5eQwbhsR

President Biden on Tuesday vehemently defended his decision to end America’s war in Afghanistan, saying the choice was "between leaving or escalating."
"I was not going to extend this forever war," Biden declared. https://t.co/hJ4fh29LNA

Social Security will be depleted in 2033, a year earlier than previously projected, according to a government report, as the pandemic has drained revenues and put additional strain on one of the U.S.’s most important social safety net programs. https://t.co/FmiLY5UNsL

A New Jersey woman who went by AntiVaxMomma on Instagram was charged in Manhattan on Tuesday with a conspiracy to sell hundreds of fake coronavirus vaccination cards over the social media platform. https://t.co/slumYpnLCs

Florida is cutting funds to school districts that defied Gov. Ron DeSantis’s ban on mask mandates. It is one of five states being investigated by the U.S. Education Department over such prohibitions. https://t.co/9c4E6t1qvJ
Breaking News: Mike Richards, who lasted one day of filming as host of "Jeopardy!," will exit the job of executive producer as well, Sony said. https://t.co/S9O3Vrrm26

The lashing winds have ceased and the downpours have stopped, but despite Hurricane Ida’s departure from Louisiana, recovery is far away for a state that is no stranger to storms and their aftermath. https://t.co/Sf0AuMLMuV https://t.co/OTo1f6mK8X

A federal judge on Monday struck down a Trump-era environmental rule that allowed the discharge of pollutants such as fertilizers, pesticides and industrial chemicals into millions of streams and wetlands across the U.S. https://t.co/AwG1u88hy6

About 70% of adults in the EU have been fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, officials said, a milestone that puts the bloc among the world’s leaders in vaccinations despite a fumbling start. https://t.co/tyTBSXdZAv

China has tightened restrictions on online gaming. Children and teenagers can't play on school days, and are limited to an hour a day of gaming on Fridays, weekends and holidays. https://t.co/htoHm8rDTJ
The front page of The New York Times for Aug. 31, 2021. https://t.co/hL9nNirZri

The last U.S. forces left Afghanistan late Monday, ending a 20-year occupation that cost over $2 trillion, took more than 170,000 lives, left behind tens of thousands of Afghans and ultimately failed to defeat the Taliban. https://t.co/XurOiLd0Xc

Defense Department officials said a drone strike in Kabul on Sunday had blown up a vehicle laden with explosives. But survivors said 10 people, including seven children, were killed.
"I saw the whole scene. There were burnt pieces of flesh everywhere." https://t.co/qpBBypDBkG https://t.co/iOdNIkkON8
The front page of The New York Times for Aug. 30, 2021. https://t.co/O8L63XG5Dk

"Conditions are still severe throughout the city of New Orleans," Mayor LaToya Cantrell said Monday after about a million customers were without power following Hurricane Ida. Follow for updates. https://t.co/JaCG6pGVE3 https://t.co/KlFGxfOT7f

A federal judge on Monday struck down a Trump-era environmental rule that allowed the discharge of pollutants such as fertilizers, pesticides and industrial chemicals into millions of streams and wetlands across the U.S. https://t.co/9WPohWsIG5

In Opinion
“What’s beyond debate is that Biden’s execution of his own policy has been a fiasco,” Bret Stephens tells Gail Collins in their latest conversation. “He made the United States look humiliated, incompetent and weak.” https://t.co/T9jUtQTg4k

New data confirm that the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines carry a small risk of rare heart problems, most common in adolescent boys and young men. Still, the benefits of vaccination outweigh the risks, scientists said. https://t.co/2wjGnspaqH
The home page of The New York Times at 5:20 p.m. Eastern on Aug. 30, 2021. https://t.co/klS0wPzeML
Average daily Covid hospitalizations in the U.S. surpassed 100,000 patients over the past week, a level not seen since the peak last winter. https://t.co/FBYVLPwHKw
Breaking News: The U.S. military has departed Afghanistan, officials said, ending a 20-year occupation and leaving the country in the Taliban’s hands. https://t.co/0Ef0cGJs41

Breaking News: The Education Department is investigating five states with bans on mask mandates, saying they may run afoul of civil rights laws protecting students with disabilities. https://t.co/3WL8NUi7Cs

The coronavirus has caused “the most catastrophic disruption of education in history,” and it’s vital for children’s learning and mental health that schools take measures to open and continue in-person lessons, the WHO’s top European official said. https://t.co/PQV8iSat2q

Though it has not been shown to be effective in treating Covid-19, people are now clamoring to get ivermectin, an anti-parasite drug commonly used in animals.
"You are not a horse," the Food and Drug Administration tweeted on Aug. 21. https://t.co/iFPefnv7UO

The $14.5 billion flood-protection system built around New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina seems to have succeeded at keeping the city from going underwater again. But that narrow success doesn’t mean residents are safe, as many remain without power. https://t.co/H5VL3Mg86y

President Biden made an unannounced appearance at Dover Air Force Base on Sunday to receive the remains of the 13 soldiers killed in the Kabul bombing. They were on their way from Afghanistan, via Kuwait and Germany, to final rest in the U.S. https://t.co/LQx1MGeOO3 https://t.co/3ig6WBzZ2K

“I’m convinced this movie couldn’t have been done in the U.S.” When “Y Tu Mamá También” opened in Mexico, the movie upended the lives of its filmmakers and stars. Twenty years later, they revisit the film in an interview with The New York Times. https://t.co/9sbn9d2QO7

Breaking News: The E.U. recommended reimposing travel restrictions for unvaccinated U.S. visitors. The change is not mandatory, and each member state imposes its own rules and can decide whether to follow the guidelines. https://t.co/17HjDNNhm9

A silent majority of American workers do want to get back to the office, at least for a few days a week. As coronavirus cases rise and companies keep workplaces closed, these frustrated employees can’t wait to return to their cubicles.
https://t.co/ele90OIqRB

Family members said 10 people, including seven children, were killed by a U.S. drone strike in Kabul on Sunday.
“At first I thought it was the Taliban,” one survivor said. “But the Americans themselves did it.” https://t.co/R0EzvPAgJg
Tens of millions of older Americans who cannot afford dental care may soon get help as Democrats maneuver to add dental benefits to Medicare for the first time in its history. https://t.co/K27A3tl9rJ

“I feel sick to my stomach watching this hurricane."
As Hurricane Ida closed in on the Louisiana coast on Sunday morning, meteorologists were stunned to watch the storm strengthen so quickly. https://t.co/3KTU6HGqoE

Students from the American University of Kabul have been denied flights out of the country by the U.S. military.
According to four students, the university informed the group that their names and passport information had been shared with the Taliban. https://t.co/atcy6REbLr

Tens of millions of older Americans who cannot afford dental care may soon get help as Democrats maneuver to add dental benefits to Medicare for the first time in its history. https://t.co/uYqSCSYTOH https://t.co/z1mmwJZm2P

Watch: President Biden joined the families of 13 U.S. service members killed in a bombing at the Kabul airport in Afghanistan last week, as their remains were brought to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware. https://t.co/C3WXPwqgZK https://t.co/W7YEek8p4Y

Hurricane Ida gained power faster than most storms. Because of climate change, such rapid strengthening is happening more often as hurricanes pick up more energy from ocean water that is warmer than before. https://t.co/oAQhz5YEdP

“I feel sick to my stomach watching this hurricane."
As Hurricane Ida closed in on the Louisiana coast on Sunday morning, meteorologists were stunned to watch the storm strengthen so quickly. https://t.co/V8PsaNQxnt

Hurricane Ida made landfall near Port Fourchon, Louisiana on the 16th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, slamming the southeastern coast with dangerous winds and storm surge.
Follow for updates: https://t.co/HOEhC9sbT4 https://t.co/18ggIUBsU5

The U.S. and 97 other countries said on Sunday that they would continue to take in people fleeing Afghanistan after the American military departs next week and had secured an agreement with the Taliban to allow safe passage for those who are leaving. https://t.co/23hraRArS2
Ed Asner, the Emmy-winning character actor best known as Lou Grant, the gruff but lovable newsman first introduced on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” has died at 91. https://t.co/biw0osLwAm
On the final day of her trip to Southeast Asia, Vice President Kamala Harris said that the U.S. would work with allies to protect women and children in Afghanistan. https://t.co/c4px8z11Oq

One of the last photos that Marine Sgt. Nicole Gee shared with her family shows her amid the chaos of Kabul, carefully cradling a baby.
She was killed not long after, one of two women in uniform who died during this week's suicide bombing. https://t.co/5JW9Eg1iZe

President Biden was set to fly to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware on Sunday morning to join the families of the 13 members of the U.S. military who were killed in a bombing last week in Afghanistan.
These are their names. https://t.co/S66t5TMGhp https://t.co/VfxtLQouWg

Faced with high stress levels among adolescents and a mental health crisis that includes worsening suicide rates, some states are now allowing students to declare a mental health day. https://t.co/dAOsrmhg2m
He’s lap dancing on the devil and winning the internet. Hear how Lil Nas X is redefining what a pop star can be. https://t.co/1AuEh8FMK0 https://t.co/3o95gwi6DT

Caleb Wallace, a leader of the anti-mask movement in central Texas, has died after being infected with the coronavirus and spending three weeks in the ICU, his wife, Jessica, said on Saturday. He was 30. https://t.co/ttNmn2yy2b

Giant tortoises were believed to be herbivorous. For the first time, scientists in the Seychelles captured footage of one of the hulking reptiles stalking and killing a baby bird.
"It's totally surprising and rather horrifying," one said. https://t.co/5NCL8WhlcM https://t.co/BFZqPwtNoc

Steve Martin. Martin Short. Selena Gomez.
The three stars are teaming up for "Only Murders in the Building," an arch sendup of cutthroat New York life that's also a murder mystery. https://t.co/4TTaoVku5Q

In Opinion
Elliot Ackerman writes: “Never have I witnessed a greater, swifter collapse of competence than what I have seen with the U.S. evacuation of Afghanistan.” https://t.co/ew7IXSgmEX
Some female hummingbirds can take on feathers to appear essentially identical to males to avoid being chased and pecked at. https://t.co/gKR4YB4ezf
